SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Apparently Greece is seeking another bailout from the international monetary fund, Germany will bare the brunt of it.
From what I've read, Greece has a massive tax evasion problem.
So how can they repay their government debts to the other euro member countries if they can't collect the money to make the payments?
Why is there even a discussion?
If Greece leaves the euro, how is that worse then the euro countries continuing to rack up debts that may never be paid back?

OP, rest assured, it's freakishly complicated. Greece has had a lot of problems in their government. Taxpayers paid alot into the system and are now being extraordinarily squeezed. It's not a simple situation with simple answers. It's quite sad, IMO.
Germany has bared the news that it will bear the brunt of it.
Wonder what Sophocles and Socrates would say!
Germany has bared the news that it will bear the brunt of it.
Wonder what Sophocles and Socrates would say!
Like a parent that keeps enabling the mid 30's "kid" that can't handle money.
You can't spend above your means forever, not as an individual or country.
There doesn't seem to be any solution, but to keep supporting them, or let them crash and burn and that will have unintended consequences destabilizing the region.
I've been trying to get a handle on this mess, but despite last weekend's vote, I think, in the end, that the Greeks feared their country’s exit from the euro more than Germany did.

Tsipras thought Greece would get less austerity and more debt relief if it waited until the last moment before debt default, believing the EU would get scared of the destabilizing fallout from a Greek euro exit. But this proved an epic miscalculation. While the Greeks overwhelmingly rejected their creditors’ demands, Germany hardened its line. Germany's finance chief told Greece on Saturday that they could take a five-year “timeout” from the euro.
But Greece has debt, debt and more debt, and no currency of its own. What the hell is a drachma going to be worth, after exiting the euro? Their banking system would collapse within days.

From what I've been able to find as of this moment, the Greeks will be living under draconian measures as the price of avoiding financial collapse and being ejected from the euro. Tsipras is balking on only 2 points: the involvement of the IMF in the new bailout and on a German demand to park 50 billion euros in assets outside Greece to serve as collateral for fresh loans.
Frankly, I think the EU is simply kicking the can down the road. But I'm NOT a believer in the magical powers of austerity measures.
Since Germany and Austria are basically supporting the entire European economy at this point, how long will it be before they simply repossess Greece?
It is indeed a huge mess. One that could, and should, have been resolved long ago. But the Austerians refused to do so.

From what I've been able to find as of this moment, the Greeks will be living under draconian measures as the price of avoiding financial collapse and being ejected from the euro. Tsipras is balking on only 2 points: the involvement of the IMF in the new bailout and on a German demand to park 50 billion euros in assets outside Greece to serve as collateral for fresh loans.
Those are really big points, though. accepting those demands is tantamount to handing over national authority in some major areas. That would be on top of the imposed austerity!
I agree that the tax collection issue must be addressed. But the rest seems pretty d@mn dubious to me.

The only good thing about an Grexit is that they could lower the cost of exports. They could also make serious mischief for the EU on immigration from the east and south. There is value to the EU to have a stable Greece at it's southern flank.

I think Krugman's assessment is spot on. This current offer is actually designed to be an offer the Greeks cannot accept. Schauble wants Greece out of the Euro. In no small part because Tsipras is standing up against austerity as a useful policy. "German morality economics" is exactly what this is, now.

I have far more respect for Greece and the Greeks than to compare them to a lazy "kid". Note this historic context from a background column today--the trashing of Greece's economy by outsiders is nothing new:

But in a proud, impractical and stirring exercise of national sovereignty, the country thumbed its nose at the Allies. Constantine returned to the throne that December. Angered, <b>france and Britain set up a financial blockade, withholding loans that been promised during the world war and that remained payable to the Greeks. The United States also reneged on loans. <b> The drachma lost much of its value. Greece was isolated.

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/13/opinion/greek-defiance-has-a-history.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Homepage&amp;module=opinion-c-col-left-region&amp;region=opinion-c-col-left-region&amp;WT.nav=opinion-c-col-left-region" target="_blank">Urenek: Greek Defiance has a Long History</a>
And here's The Economist (that liberal rag!) on why debt forgiveness would be the correct response and the parallels (and non-parallels) with the Marshall Plan:
<a href="http://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2012/06/economic-history" target="_blank">Ritschl: Germany, Greece and the Marshall Plan</a>
A few bullet points I think it is useful to bear in mind:

--On poor Germany being stuck holding the bag. That is German BANKS. (Or it was at the outset before the Greek debt was endlessly restructured and massaged.) The bailout is a bailout for German,<u>banks<u>.

--On austerity. Back before the neocons ran the show, how did we rebuild economies? Well, the biggie in Europe was the Marshall Plan. Debt forgiveness coupled with trade integration. US Marshall Plan money became the 'first charge'--no other loans could be paid before the Marshall Plan 'loans'.

--On a 'timeout' exit from the Euro. Good luck ever getting back in. And good luck to those countries that stay in--how will your currency ever be stable if countries can come and go? It will be a shadow currency if this becomes the strategy.

--On insistence that the rules on debt be followed by members of the EU. France has missed their debt targets for multiple quarters. Italy is in the same situation. (This, BTW is why other countries--including small, prosperous, Austria that took and continues to take a non-austerity approach to dealing with the recession--oppose the German approach.) Yet somehow, the rules are different for the larger, richer, more powerful players than for Greece.
I don't know how this is going to play out, but I wish the Greek people the very best. They may be few, but they matter in the world.
Since Germany and Austria are basically supporting the entire European economy at this point, how long will it be before they simply repossess Greece?
Repossess? They never possessed it. And a wink-grin? Wow.
The Greeks stood up to Mussolini and suffered terribly at the hands of the Axis.
The island of Crete was pivotal in the movement of intell about the Axis.
Zonderpaard -- thanks for providing your insights.

It is a complex situation and one that starts with that the Greeks have had a terrible economy for decades They have problems with tax collection, over promising on pensions, a low participation rate on employment, etc.

The situation also points out a major problem with the unified currency concept that a sovereign nation that has no control over its currency. Comapre to the united states that has been madly printing money for the past several years. Why? To make it cheaper to pay back debts and to encourage exports. Under the eurozone, the greeks cannot do that.

So they are kind of stuck. Some in the Euro want them out and their own Prime Minister and his party want them out.If they take the exit, their economy will sink further but they will gain some independent access to so monetary tools.
I wouldn't want to be living in greece or trying to run a business there.

I was in Greece a few days ago, and it's very hard for people. The people I spoke to who are paying tax have to pay over 50% , prices are high, insurance is high. It's very tough there. I feel sorry for them.
If Greece leaves the euro, how is that worse then the euro countries continuing to rack up debts that may never be paid back?
I wonder the same about AMTRACK which hasn't made any money, each ticket is subsidized by the government at about $60 yet we continue to pour money into a hole that becomes deeper

I feel sorry for them too but you get what you vote for. Decades of unrealistic programs and a culture that turns a blind eye to tax evasion don't mix.

--On poor Germany being stuck holding the bag. That is German BANKS. (Or it was at the outset before the Greek debt was endlessly restructured and massaged.) The bailout is a bailout for German <u>banks<u>.
It was last time, I think? Bailed out by the IMF and ECB, and the current crisis precipitated by a default to the IMF?

That bailout was not so much a bailout of Greece, as it was a bailout of Greece's lenders. Who feel secure lending to Greece because they expected a bailout. This whole "we can lend to bankrupt countries because they (ie we) will get bailed out" scheme has needs addressing too.

I don't know if it would help long term, but I wish everyone pondering a holiday would consider going to Greece. In terms of a holiday destination it has everything one could ask for and is reasonably priced.

Yesterday, the gate next to mine was a flight to Athens out of Paris-CDG. Packed plane. It cannot hurt. And yes, a spectacular place to go for lots and lots of reasons. I hope to go again someday myself.
In the meantime, I'm buying this remarkable stuff:

National currency is an important financial tool, allowing governments to adjust their currency against others, making their goods less expensive than other countries and attracting capital. The EU removed that tool.
If Greece lined up their banks and prepared for a cut over to the drachma, all their goods, including tourism, would generate a stream of wealth.
Those who Are pro-exit in Greek politics should be busy making it a smoother transition to the drachma.

National currency is an important financial tool, allowing governments to adjust their currency against others, making their goods less expensive than other countries and attracting capital. The EU removed that tool.
If Greece lined up their banks and prepared for a cut over to the drachma, all their goods, including tourism, would generate a stream of wealth.
Those who Are pro-exit in Greek politics should be busy making it a smoother transition to the drachma.

Yeah, but who is going to loan to them? How do you value a drachma on the world currency market? It's not so simple. And once they re-open banks, drawers stocked with drachmas, do you really think there wouldn't be a bank run? (There may be anyway even if they stay on the Euro.)
You can rest assured that plenty of people who were working on a Grexit transition plan. They had actually thought of that . . . .

It does look like there as a 'Agreekment', however. It looks pretty rough on Greece, to me. Will see if Tsipras survives. They may call an election and run him out. Good luck to the Germans on who the Greek voters might put in there in his place.
What most of us are missing is Goldman Sach's involvement in hiding Greek debt during before and during Greece's entrance into the Eurozone, using...drumroll...derivatives and swaps.
There's some possibility that Greece may be able to claw back some of the profits on that deal with a lawsuit.
